page.title: 19ECOLOGY:WOKINGHAM
page.content: On this{sandy acid soil}the native trees (silver birch, oak and Scot's pine) are now confined to small areas of woodland and gardens.{Hedgerows}are common despite the recent ravages of Dutch Elm disease. Housing and agricultural needs have meant some {loss of woodland}and, therefore, of violets, heather and also the wood-ant. Peacock and Small Tortoiseshell{butterflies}are common but High Brown and Pearl-bordered Fritillary butterflies have disappeared. Many{birds,}such as magpies and jays, are adapting to gardens. Man-made pools have encouraged an increase in{frogs and {toads. Grey squirrels}are common;{deer and{foxes}are occasionally seen. Since the 1960s many oaks are attacked annually by the Knopper gall. Public footpaths are well-marked.
